====State consequentialism====
  +
{{Main|Mohist consequentialism}}
  +   +
[[Mohist consequentialism]], also known as state consequentialism,<ref name="readings">{{Cite book| title = Readings in classical Chinese philosophy | year = 2005 | last =Ivanhoe | first = P.J. | last2= Van Norden | first2= Bryan William |publisher = [[Hackett Publishing]] | isbn = 978-0-87-220780-6|page=60|quote="he advocated a form of state consequentialism, which sought to maximize three basic goods: the wealth, order, and population of the state}}</ref> is an ethical theory which evaluates the moral worth of an action based on how much it contributes to the social harmony of a state.<ref name="readings"/> The ''[[Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]]'' describes Mohist consequentialism, dating back to the 5th century BC, as "a remarkably sophisticated version based on a plurality of intrinsic goods taken as constitutive of human welfare."<ref>Fraser, Chris, "[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/mohism/ Mohism]", ''[[The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]]'' , Edward N. Zalta.</ref> Unlike utilitarianism, which views pleasure as a moral good, "the basic goods in Mohist consequentialist thinking are... order, material wealth, and increase in population".<ref name="Cambridge">{{Cite book| title = [[The Cambridge History of Ancient China]] | year = 1999 | last =Loewe | first = Michael | last2= Shaughnessy | first2= Edward L. |publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] | isbn = 978-0-52-147030-8|page=761}}</ref> During [[Mozi]]'s era, war and famines were common, and population growth was seen as a moral necessity for a harmonious society. The "material wealth" of Mohist consequentialism refers to [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs|basic needs]] like shelter and clothing, and the "order" of Mohist consequentialism refers to Mozi's stance against warfare and violence, which he viewed as pointless and a threat to social stability.<ref name="Norden"/> [[Stanford University|Stanford]] [[sinologist]] [[David S. Nivison|David Shepherd Nivison]], in the ''[[The Cambridge History of Ancient China]]'', writes that the moral goods of Mohism "are interrelated: more basic wealth, then more reproduction; more people, then more production and wealth... if people have plenty, they would be good, filial, kind, and so on unproblematically."<ref name="Cambridge"/> In contrast to Bentham, Mozi did not believe that individual happiness was important, the consequences of the [[state]] outweigh the consequences of individual actions.<ref name="Cambridge"/>
